@DeanPrelazzi not sure I understand the question - start-ups are about innovating and need to play all 3 dimension as they grow up...
@vilcsak you are working in the perfect company to observe that in short order :-)
@isuruayw depends a bit on your convictions & resources. Jeff Bezos has a history of launching several attempts to solve a specific problem.
5/ The best companies (Facebook, Google, Amazon, Apple) excel in all 3 dimensions
4/ Long-term: have a big vision and be stubborn to achieve that vision (often through several attempts at cracking a problem)
3/ Mid-term: need to place big bets from time to time that redefine your business and / or open up completely new opportunities
2/ Short-term: incremental innovation through hundreds of little improvements to product / marketing / sales every week ("a/b testing")
1/ Think about innovation in start-ups in 3 time horizons: short-term, mid-term, long-term

7/ Net/net: great companies can get build everywhere but paths are very different - comes down to founder ambition and mindset.
6/ Interesting recent development: companies getting started outside SV, get SV mindset during YC, go back to build their companies
5/ BUT: scaling outside of SV tougher b/c of a lack of senior talent (VP level) - need to relocate people and / or open 2nd office
4/ SV brutal in that way. Many smaller start-ups having tough time hiring strong engineers / designers, especially in "un-sexy" areas.
3/ It is often easier to start a great company in a smaller ecosystem b/c you face less competition for the initial talent you need to hire.
2/ My conviction is that you absolutely can but different paths (though both very hard)
